Utilities for handling with rows and columns

Source: R/utilities.R
utils-rows-cols.Rd

  • add_cols(): Add one or more columns to an existing data frame. If specified before or after columns does not exist, columns are appended at the end of the data. Return a data frame with all the original columns in .data plus the columns declared in ....

  • concatenate(): Concatenate either two columns of a data frame or a column and specified values. Return a data frame with all the original columns in .data plus the concatenated variable, after the last column.

  • column_exists(): Checks if a column exists in a data frame. Return a logical value.

  • get_levels(): Get the levels of a factor variable.

  • get_level_size(): Get the size of each level of a factor variable.

  • get_all_pairs(): Get all the possible pairs between the levels of a factor.

  • select_numeric_cols(): Select all the numeric columns of a data frame.

  • select_non_numeric_cols(): Select all the non-numeric columns of a data frame.

add_columns(.data, ..., before = NULL, after = NULL)

add_rows(.data, ..., before = NULL, after = NULL)

concatenate(.data, col_1, col_2, var_name = new_var, sep = "_")

column_exists(.data, cols)

get_levels(.data, group)

get_level_size(.data, group)

all_pairs(.data, levels)

select_numeric_cols(.data)

select_non_numeric_cols(.data)

Arguments

.data

A data frame
...

Name-value pairs. All values must have one element for each row in .data when using add_cols or one element for each column in .data when using add_rows. Values of length 1 will be recycled when using add_cols.
before, after

For add_cols, one-based column index or column name where to add the new columns, default: after last column. For add_rows, one-based row index where to add the new rows, default: after last row.
col_1, col_2

An unquoted variable name for the first and second columns to concatenate, respectively. If both columns are in .data, the values of those columns will be concatenated. Else, col_1 or col_2 must be a numeric or a character vector of length equals to the number of rows in .data. Vectors of length 1 will be recycled.
var_name

The name of the new variable containing the concatenated values from col_1 and col_2. Defaults to new_var.
sep

The separator to be between values of col_1 and col_2. Defaults to "_".
cols

A quoted variable name to check if it exists in .data
group

A factor variable to get the levels.
levels

The levels of a factor or a numeric vector.

Examples

# \donttest{
library(metan)

################# Adding columns #################
# Variables x and y after last column
data_ge %>%
  add_columns(x = 10,
              y = 30)
#> # A tibble: 420 x 7
#>    ENV   GEN   REP      GY    HM     x     y
#>    <fct> <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 E1    G1    1      2.17  44.9    10    30
#>  2 E1    G1    2      2.50  46.9    10    30
#>  3 E1    G1    3      2.43  47.8    10    30
#>  4 E1    G2    1      3.21  45.2    10    30
#>  5 E1    G2    2      2.93  45.3    10    30
#>  6 E1    G2    3      2.56  45.5    10    30
#>  7 E1    G3    1      2.77  46.7    10    30
#>  8 E1    G3    2      3.62  43.2    10    30
#>  9 E1    G3    3      2.28  47.8    10    30
#> 10 E1    G4    1      2.36  47.9    10    30
#> # … with 410 more rows
# Variables x and y before the variable GEN
data_ge %>%
  add_columns(x = 10,
              y = 30,
              before = "GEN")
#> # A tibble: 420 x 7
#>    ENV       x     y GEN   REP      GY    HM
#>    <fct> <dbl> <dbl> <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 E1       10    30 G1    1      2.17  44.9
#>  2 E1       10    30 G1    2      2.50  46.9
#>  3 E1       10    30 G1    3      2.43  47.8
#>  4 E1       10    30 G2    1      3.21  45.2
#>  5 E1       10    30 G2    2      2.93  45.3
#>  6 E1       10    30 G2    3      2.56  45.5
#>  7 E1       10    30 G3    1      2.77  46.7
#>  8 E1       10    30 G3    2      3.62  43.2
#>  9 E1       10    30 G3    3      2.28  47.8
#> 10 E1       10    30 G4    1      2.36  47.9
#> # … with 410 more rows

########### Concatenating columns ################
# Both variables in data
concatenate(data_ge, ENV, GEN)
#> # A tibble: 420 x 6
#>    ENV   GEN   REP      GY    HM new_var
#>    <fct> <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  
#>  1 E1    G1    1      2.17  44.9 E1_G1  
#>  2 E1    G1    2      2.50  46.9 E1_G1  
#>  3 E1    G1    3      2.43  47.8 E1_G1  
#>  4 E1    G2    1      3.21  45.2 E1_G2  
#>  5 E1    G2    2      2.93  45.3 E1_G2  
#>  6 E1    G2    3      2.56  45.5 E1_G2  
#>  7 E1    G3    1      2.77  46.7 E1_G3  
#>  8 E1    G3    2      3.62  43.2 E1_G3  
#>  9 E1    G3    3      2.28  47.8 E1_G3  
#> 10 E1    G4    1      2.36  47.9 E1_G4  
#> # … with 410 more rows

# One variable in data
concatenate(data_ge, ENV, rep(1:14, each=30))
#> # A tibble: 420 x 6
#>    ENV   GEN   REP      GY    HM new_var
#>    <fct> <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  
#>  1 E1    G1    1      2.17  44.9 E1_1   
#>  2 E1    G1    2      2.50  46.9 E1_1   
#>  3 E1    G1    3      2.43  47.8 E1_1   
#>  4 E1    G2    1      3.21  45.2 E1_1   
#>  5 E1    G2    2      2.93  45.3 E1_1   
#>  6 E1    G2    3      2.56  45.5 E1_1   
#>  7 E1    G3    1      2.77  46.7 E1_1   
#>  8 E1    G3    2      3.62  43.2 E1_1   
#>  9 E1    G3    3      2.28  47.8 E1_1   
#> 10 E1    G4    1      2.36  47.9 E1_1   
#> # … with 410 more rows

# One variable in data, recycling the second one.
concatenate(data_ge, ENV, 1)
#> # A tibble: 420 x 6
#>    ENV   GEN   REP      GY    HM new_var
#>    <fct> <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  
#>  1 E1    G1    1      2.17  44.9 E1_1   
#>  2 E1    G1    2      2.50  46.9 E1_1   
#>  3 E1    G1    3      2.43  47.8 E1_1   
#>  4 E1    G2    1      3.21  45.2 E1_1   
#>  5 E1    G2    2      2.93  45.3 E1_1   
#>  6 E1    G2    3      2.56  45.5 E1_1   
#>  7 E1    G3    1      2.77  46.7 E1_1   
#>  8 E1    G3    2      3.62  43.2 E1_1   
#>  9 E1    G3    3      2.28  47.8 E1_1   
#> 10 E1    G4    1      2.36  47.9 E1_1   
#> # … with 410 more rows

# None variables in data
# Set name of the concatenate variable
# Set the separator symbol
concatenate(data_ge,
            col_1 = rep("ENV", 420),
            col_2 = rep(1:14, each=30),
            var_name = ENVIRONMENT,
            sep = "-")
#> # A tibble: 420 x 6
#>    ENV   GEN   REP      GY    HM ENVIRONMENT
#>    <fct> <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>      
#>  1 E1    G1    1      2.17  44.9 ENV-1      
#>  2 E1    G1    2      2.50  46.9 ENV-1      
#>  3 E1    G1    3      2.43  47.8 ENV-1      
#>  4 E1    G2    1      3.21  45.2 ENV-1      
#>  5 E1    G2    2      2.93  45.3 ENV-1      
#>  6 E1    G2    3      2.56  45.5 ENV-1      
#>  7 E1    G3    1      2.77  46.7 ENV-1      
#>  8 E1    G3    2      3.62  43.2 ENV-1      
#>  9 E1    G3    3      2.28  47.8 ENV-1      
#> 10 E1    G4    1      2.36  47.9 ENV-1      
#> # … with 410 more rows

################### Adding rows ##################
data_ge %>%
  add_rows(ENV = "E_TEST",
           GEN = "G_TEST",
           REP = 3,
           GY = 10.3,
           HM = 100.11,
           after = 1)
#> # A tibble: 421 x 5
#>    ENV    GEN    REP      GY    HM
#>    <fct>  <fct>  <fct> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 E1     G1     1      2.17  44.9
#>  2 E_TEST G_TEST 3     10.3  100. 
#>  3 E1     G1     2      2.50  46.9
#>  4 E1     G1     3      2.43  47.8
#>  5 E1     G2     1      3.21  45.2
#>  6 E1     G2     2      2.93  45.3
#>  7 E1     G2     3      2.56  45.5
#>  8 E1     G3     1      2.77  46.7
#>  9 E1     G3     2      3.62  43.2
#> 10 E1     G3     3      2.28  47.8
#> # … with 411 more rows
########## checking if a column exists ###########
column_exists(data_g, "GEN")
#> [1] TRUE

####### get the levels and size of levels ########
get_levels(data_g, GEN)
#>  [1] "H1"  "H10" "H11" "H12" "H13" "H2"  "H3"  "H4"  "H5"  "H6"  "H7"  "H8" 
#> [13] "H9" 
get_level_size(data_g, GEN)
#>  H1 H10 H11 H12 H13  H2  H3  H4  H5  H6  H7  H8  H9 
#>   3   3   3   3   3   3   3   3   3   3   3   3   3 

############## all possible pairs ################
all_pairs(data_g, GEN)
#>     [,1]  [,2] 
#> V1  "H1"  "H10"
#> V2  "H1"  "H11"

########## select numeric variables only #########
select_numeric_cols(data_g)
#> # A tibble: 39 x 15
#>       PH    EH    EP    EL    ED    CL    CD    CW    KW    NR   NKR  CDED  PERK
#>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>

#> # … with 29 more rows, and 2 more variables: TKW <dbl>, NKE <dbl>
select_non_numeric_cols(data_g)
#> # A tibble: 39 x 2

# }
